questions.text:
An 80-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate acute chest pain. Before obtaining a clinical history, the patient becomes unresponsive. Temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 186/92 mmHg. A chest radiograph is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Large cell adenocarcinoma of the lung

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of acute chest pain. Chest radiography demonstrates a widened mediastinum, which can be due to many possible etiologies. However, of the diagnoses listed, only a thoracic aortic aneurysm is causative of a widened mediastinum.  

The mediastinum is the central thoracic cavity that contains the heart, esophagus, trachea, thoracic duct, thymus, and lymph nodes of the central chest. Radiographically, this space is defined by the right heart border, ascending aorta, superior vena cava, aortic knob, descending aorta, and left heart border. A widened mediastinum is defined as greater than 6-8 cm and can be caused by several pathologies.  

Most importantly, the life-threatening etiologies of a widened mediastinum include aortic pathologies such as traumatic rupture of the aorta, aortic dissection, and thoracic aortic aneurysm. Additional etiologies of a widened mediastinum include hilar lymphadenopathy, mediastinal masses, mediastinitis, cardiac tamponade, and vascular anomalies.   

Option Analysis

✅ Thoracic aortic aneurysm  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Large cell adenocarcinoma of the lung:
Incorrect: The lung's large cell adenocarcinoma presents radiographically as a large radiopaque mass with irregular margins. It would not typically present with mediastinal widening.
❌ Massive pulmonary embolism :
Incorrect: A massive pulmonary embolism often demonstrates pulmonary venous congestion and prominence of the right heart border. It would not cause mediastinal widening. 
❌ Left ventricular aneurysm:
Incorrect: Left ventricular aneurysm may demonstrate an enlarged cardiac silhouette but would not cause widening of the mediastinum.   
❌ Esophageal rupture :
Incorrect: Esophageal rupture is most commonly caused by instrumentation, trauma, or forceful vomiting. Patients present with severe retrosternal chest pain that may increase with swallowing or deep breathing. While patients can have some widening of the mediastinum, patients also frequently have subcutaneous and mediastinal emphysema.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. The patient was a restrained driver when he suddenly slammed into the back of a stopped truck while traveling approximately 70 miles per hour. Upon arrival at the emergency department, the patient has a Glasgow coma scale of 4 and is subsequently intubated for airway protection. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 144/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 67/30 mmHg. Physical examination shows bruising over the anterior chest wall, but no crepitus is felt on palpation. A chest X-ray is obtained and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical condition?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Rotary force applied to the torso
Vertical compression force applied to the neck
Penetrating trauma to the left anterior chest

questions.solution:
Traumatic rupture of the aorta is a potentially life-threatening injury, with most cases occurring due to sudden deceleration related to automobile accidents.  

Approximately 80-90% of aortic tears occur in the descending aorta at the isthmus, which is just distal to the left subclavian artery and firmly tethered by the ligamentum arteriosum. The more mobile aortic arch swings forward during deceleration, producing a shearing force or “whiplash effect” on the aorta at the isthmus. This shearing force at the isthmus results in a tear. A widened mediastinum may be visible on chest radiography. Many patients will have retrosternal or scapular pain.  

Less common sites of aortic trauma include the ascending aorta, distal descending aorta at the level of the diaphragm, and the mid-thoracic descending aorta because these areas of the aorta are more anatomically fixed and thus less subject to movement in rapid deceleration.  

Option Analysis

✅ Sudden deceleration :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Direct, blunt anterior chest trauma :
Incorrect: Blunt chest trauma may result in sternal fractures, rib fractures, and cardiac or pulmonary contusions. It is not the most common mechanism of injury associated with aortic rupture. 
❌ Rotary force applied to the torso:
Incorrect: A rotary force applied to the torso is not the most common mechanism associated with traumatic rupture of the aorta. 
❌ Vertical compression force applied to the neck:
Incorrect: A burst fracture of C1 is also known as a Jefferson fracture and is considered an unstable C-spine injury. It often occurs due to a vertical compression force applied to the neck. 
❌ Penetrating trauma to the left anterior chest:
Incorrect: Penetrating trauma to the left anterior chest is a less common cause of the traumatic aortic rupture. Penetrating trauma to the left anterior chest is more likely to result in cardiac tamponade, pneumothorax, or perforation of the right ventricle.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate syncope and right flank pain. The patient experienced severe right-sided flank pain radiating to the groin while getting out of bed this morning. He subsequently “blacked out.” His partner found him on the ground moaning in pain and brought him to the emergency department. The patient has a remote history of kidney stones. He has not seen a physician in many years. He has been smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for fifty years. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), blood pressure is 93/67 mmHg, pulse is 102/min, and O2 saturation is 94% on room air. Physical exam demonstrates a tachypneic male in moderate pain. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. An abdominal radiograph is shown below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
Which of the following best identifies the anatomic location of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
An older patient with a significant smoking history presents with unexplained syncope following severe flank pain. Abdominal radiography demonstrates calcification and ballooning of the abdominal aorta. These findings are concerning for a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm with impending rupture.

The vast majority of aortic aneurysms are present in the infrarenal region and are clinically defined as dilating the aorta to greater than 50% of its normal diameter. Typically, this value is 3 cm, with large aneurysms defined as those greater than 5 cm. Known risk factors include male sex, older age, significant smoking history, uncontrolled hypertension, family history, and atherosclerotic disease. These aneurysms are due to chronic arterial wall inflammation, extracellular matrix degradation, and subsequent balloon dilation.

Clinically, most abdominal aortic aneurysms are silent and present with symptoms only at the time of rupture or impending rupture. With partial or immediate rupture, most patients present with symptoms that mimic renal colic, including back or flank pain radiating to the groin. Other findings include hypotension, abdominal pain, or a pulsatile abdominal mass (however, this finding is not always present).

In symptomatic patients, diagnosis is best achieved with CT imaging of the abdomen and pelvis. However, ultrasound can also quickly detect large aneurysms. Abdominal radiographs can detect calcifications and subsequent dilation of the aorta.  

Option Analysis

✅ Infrarenal aorta  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Suprarenal aorta  :
Incorrect: Abdominal aortic aneurysms almost always occur in the infrarenal aorta. Thoracic aortic aneurysms may occur proximal to the renal arteries and track inferiorly over time.  
❌ Ureteropelvic junction  :
Incorrect: Impacted renal stones may be present at the ureteropelvic junction. An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) often mimics the symptoms of renal colic. However, given this patient’s history and findings on abdominal radiography, a symptomatic AAA with impending rupture is more likely.  
❌ Proximal ureter  :
Incorrect: Proximal ureteral stones often present with symptoms similar to that of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Given this patient’s history and findings on abdominal radiography, a symptomatic AAA with impending rupture best explains his symptoms.  
❌ Terminal Ileum  :
Incorrect: The terminal ileum is the location of intra-abdominal pathologies, including colitis and Crohn disease. In addition, acute appendicitis can cause inflammation and wall thickening of the adjacent terminal ileum. However, given this patient’s history and findings on abdominal radiography, a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm with impending rupture best explains his symptoms.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. The patient was a restrained driver traveling on the highway when he suddenly slammed into the back of a stopped semi-truck. Upon arrival to the emergency department, the patient reports severe substernal chest pain radiating to his left shoulder blade. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 185/100 mmHg. Physical examination shows bruising over the anterior chest wall, but no crepitus is felt on palpation. Shoulder examination shows full passive and active range of motion bilaterally. A chest X-ray is obtained (see below):  



Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

Which of the following is the most likely location of injury?
questions.solution:
Traumatic rupture of the aorta is a potentially life-threatening injury, with most cases occurring due to sudden deceleration related to automobile accidents. Approximately 80-90% of aortic tears occur in the descending aorta at the isthmus, which is just distal to the left subclavian artery and strongly tethered by the ligamentum arteriosum. Many patients will have retrosternal or scapular pain, and a widened mediastinum is visible on chest x ray.  

During deceleration, the more mobile aortic arch swings forward, producing a shearing force or “whiplash effect” on the aorta at the isthmus, which is fixed due to the attachment of the ligamentum arteriosum. This shearing force at the isthmus results in a tear. Less common sites of aortic trauma include the ascending aorta, the distal descending aorta at the level of the diaphragm, and the mid-thoracic descending aorta, because these areas of the aorta are more anatomically fixed and thus less subject to movement.  



Option Analysis

✅ Aortic isthmus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Distal descending aorta:
Incorrect: While this is a potential area of trauma, it is less likely to be injured due to its relatively fixed position at the diaphragm.   
❌ Sinotubular junction:
Incorrect: This location is an uncommon site of injury and is rarely involved in traumatic aortic pathology.  
❌ Clavicle :
Incorrect: While this patient endorses shoulder pain, there is no crepitus on exam, and the patient has full range of motion of the shoulder, making a clavicular injury less likely.   
❌ Manubrium :
Incorrect: This patient does endorse retrosternal chest pain; however, no crepitus is appreciated, and there is no evidence of a fracture pattern obtained on the radiograph above.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for a fever of unknown origin. After 24 hours, the patient's blood culture from the emergency department returns positive for Gram-positive cocci in clusters. The patient subsequently undergoes transesophageal echocardiography, which produces the image as demonstrated below. Which of the following correctly identifies the structure labeled with X?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a fever of unknown origin and undergoes transesophageal echocardiography due to concern for bacteremia and endocarditis. The above image demonstrates a 4-chamber view of the heart, with the structure labeled “X” representing the mitral valve and a superior structure suspicious for vegetation.  

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is an ultrasonographic technique wherein an endoscopic transducer is advanced into the esophagus to visualize cardiac structures. TEE offers superior imaging of the heart (particularly posterior cardiac structures) compared to transthoracic echocardiography, wherein ultrasound of the anterior and lateral chest is performed. Common indications for TEE include evaluation for a potential cardiac source of an embolus, valvular endocarditis, and left atrial appendage thrombi in patients with atrial fibrillation.  

Multiple views can be obtained with TEE to help visualize the cardiac structures. Visualized structures include the ventricles, atria, mitral and tricuspid valves, atrial appendage, aortic arch, aortic leaflets, root, and pulmonary arteries and veins.  

Option Analysis

✅ Mitral valve:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Tricuspid valve:
Incorrect: On the above image, the tricuspid valve is located right and inferior to the area demarcated by the X. The tricuspid valve can be identified by first locating the right ventricle, which is smaller and has a thinner wall than the left ventricle.
❌ Aortic outlet :
Incorrect: The aortic outlet is not identified in the above image, which demonstrates a four-chamber view of the heart. 
❌ Aortic valve:
Incorrect: The aortic valve has three leaflets and is not identified in the above image, which demonstrates a four-chamber view of the heart. 
❌ Pulmonic valve:
Incorrect: The pulmonic valve has three leaflets and is not identified in the above image, which demonstrates a four-chamber view of the heart.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents for follow-up evaluation after a recent myocardial infarction. The patient had a high-grade occlusion of the left anterior descending artery with stent placement. The patient has been compliant with medications. However, he has pain and weakness in the left upper extremity with exercise. The patient states, “I know something is not right. My arm turns ghost white every time I get on the treadmill, and I feel like I will pass out.” Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. Medications include aspirin, carvedilol, amlodipine, metformin, atorvastatin, and clopidogrel. He has a twenty-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mmHg in the right arm compared with 121/65 mmHg in the left arm. The left radial pulse demonstrates arrival delay compared to the right radial pulse. The patient's left hand presents a brisk capillary refill. The patient’s cardiologist subsequently orders an ultrasound of the heart and upper extremities. Which of the following findings is most likely to be found on ultrasonographic evaluation?

choices.text: Reversal of blood flow in the left vertebral artery
Dissection flap of the proximal aorta
Deep vein thrombosis of the left subclavian vein
Thromboembolism of the left brachial artery

questions.solution:
This patient who recently underwent stent placement for acute myocardial infarction presents with signs of exertional ischemia in the left upper extremity. His findings are suspicious for subclavian steal syndrome, which will typically demonstrate flow reversal through the ipsilateral vertebral artery.   

Subclavian steal syndrome refers to a phenomenon that occurs with severe stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the ipsilateral vertebral artery – typically from underlying atherosclerotic disease. As this stenosis progresses, the pressure gradient of blood flowing through the affected subclavian artery decreases relative to the pressure gradient in the ipsilateral vertebral artery. As a result, blood flows down through the vertebral artery from the basilar vascular supply.  

Most patients are asymptomatic; however, when symptoms arise, they are typically exercise-induced. Patients can present with symptoms of ischemia to the affected upper extremity, including pain, paresthesias, pallor, and coolness to the touch. In some instances, associated neurologic symptoms may manifest, including dizziness, lightheadedness, syncope, tinnitus, or disequilibrium due to vertebrobasilar ischemia.  

Physical examination findings typically include a delayed or decreased pulse amplitude of the affected extremity and a differential brachial systolic blood pressure between the upper extremities.    

Option Analysis

✅ Reversal of blood flow in the left vertebral artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Dissection flap of the proximal aorta :
Incorrect: Aortic dissection typically presents with acute, sharp, “tearing” chest pain radiating to the back. While this patient is at risk for aortic pathology given his recent cardiac catheterization, his clinical findings are inconsistent with this diagnosis. 
❌ Deep vein thrombosis of the left subclavian vein:
Incorrect: Given his recent surgical procedure, this patient is at an increased risk for deep vein thrombosis. However, a deep vein thrombosis of the upper extremity is rare and universally presents with swelling and pain of the affected upper extremity. A pulse deficit is not typically associated with this condition. 
❌ Thromboembolism of the left brachial artery:
Incorrect: An acute thromboembolism of the left brachial artery would result in signs of acute ischemia, including pain, paresthesias, pallor, poikilothermia, pulselessness, and paralysis. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms are only present with exertion and hence unlikely to be secondary to arterial thromboembolism. 
❌ Widened aortic outflow tract :
Incorrect: Thoracic aortic aneurysms are most often asymptomatic. When symptomatic, they typically present with acute onset chest pain.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of right leg pain for three months. The pain is characterized by a continuous cramping in the right thigh that starts after walking two blocks and goes away at rest. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes, and coronary artery disease. The patient smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg. Physical exam shows decreased hair growth on the right thigh and calf compared to left. The skin on the right leg is dry and shiny. There is no swelling or tenderness. Pain does not occur with bending forwards or backwards at the waist. Which of the following muscles is directly supplied by the artery most likely involved in this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
This patient with athersclerotic risk factors is presenting with intermittent claudication in the right thigh, making peripheral artery disease (PAD) the most likely diagnosis. Claudication is characterized by cramping pain in the affected area that comes about during exercise and is relieved with rest. Peripheral artery disease, a type of peripheral vascular disease (PVD), is caused by insufficient tissue perfusion due to narrowing or occlusion of the aorta or one of the more distal branches supplying the limbs. Similar to coronary artery and cerebrovascular disease, the development of an atherosclerotic plaque that narrows or completely occludes an artery is the number one cause of peripheral artery disease, and therefore these diseases often exist together. Risk factors for atherosclerosis, such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus, smoking and hyperlipidemia, raise the suspicion for peripheral artery disease.  

The location of a patient’s pain can indicate where the occlusion is:  



This patient’s thigh pain, without pain in the hips or buttocks, suggests there is an occlusion in the femoral artery. The femoral artery gives rise to the deep femoral artery (profunda femoris) which branches to form the lateral femoral circumflex artery. The lateral femoral circumflex artery supplies blood to the rectus femoris muscle, which functions to flex the thigh at the hip joint and extend the leg at the knee joint.    

In addition to claudication, chronic limb ischemia may produce physical changes. These include decreased skin temperature (termed poikilothermia), decreased hair and nail growth, and loss of sensation. On physical exam, the pulses distal to the obstruction are weak, and there is diminished capillary refill in the affected area.  

Option Analysis

❌ Gluteus maximus:
Incorrect: The gluteus maximus (main extensor of the hip) is supplied by the superior gluteal artery, a branch of the internal iliac artery. Occlusion of the internal iliac artery would cause pain in the buttocks and hips with exertion.  
✅ Rectus femoris:
Correct: See Main Explanation below.  
❌ Quadratus femoris:
Incorrect: The quadratus femoris (external rotator and adductor of the thigh) is supplied by the inferior gluteal artery, a branch of the internal iliac artery. Occlusion of the internal iliac artery would cause pain in the buttocks and hips with exertion.  
❌ Gastrocnemius:
Incorrect: The gastrocnemius (flexor of the foot and leg) is supplied by the popliteal artery. Occlusion of the popliteal artery would cause pain below the knee but not in the thigh.  
❌ Abductor hallucis  :
Incorrect: The abductor hallucis (abductor and flexor of the great toe) is supplied by the tibial artery. Occlusion of the tibial artery would cause pain in the lower calf, ankle, and foot but not in the thigh.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of left leg pain and black discoloration of the left toes. The pain occurs with walking and resolves with rest. He first noticed a black discoloration of the toes two days ago and it has progressively worsened since then. He does not have any chest pain or shortness of breath. Past medical history is significant for diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He does not take any medications. The patient’s father died of a myocardial infarction at 60 years of age. The patient has a 35-pack year smoking history and does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.2 C (98.9 F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 135/90 mmHg. Which of the following additional clinical findings will likely be observed on further evaluation?

choices.text: Bruit on the auscultation of popliteal fossa
Reproduction of pain with passive dorsiflexion of the toes
Lack of femoral vein compressibility on doppler ultrasound

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of intermittent leg pain and black discoloration of toes in the presence of multiple risk factors (smoking, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus), is suggestive of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Further physical examination is likely to demonstrate diminished posterior tibial artery pulsations. 

Examination in patients with PAD commonly reveals diminished or absent pulses below the level of arterial stenosis as well as evidence of poor wound healing in the area(s) of poor perfusion. 

Pimenta's Point refers to an anatomical landmark to easily palpate the posterior tibial artery. This landmark is described by the midpoint on the imaginary line drawn between the bony prominences of the medial malleolus and the insertion of the Achilles tendon. Similar to posterior tibial artery pulsations, the dorsalis pedis pulse can also be decreased or absent in patients with PAD. This artery can be readily palpated lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon (or medially to the extensor digitorum longus tendon) on the dorsal surface of the foot distal to the dorsal most prominence of the navicular bone.       

Option Analysis

❌ Bruit on the auscultation of popliteal fossa :
Incorrect: A bruit of the popliteal fossa can be seen in patients with popliteal artery aneurysms. Patients typically present with edema and pain in the popliteal fossa. The aneurysm may compress adjacent nerves leading to referred pain overlying the medial aspect of the calf, ankle, or foot.  
✅ Diminished posterior tibial pulse :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Osteophytes on lateral foot x-ray :
Incorrect: Osteophytes on lateral foot x-ray are suggestive of osteoarthritis. Osteophytic pain may not disappear following exercise and varies in intensity from day-to-day (usually worse in the morning or upon waking). 
❌ Reproduction of pain with passive dorsiflexion of the toes :
Incorrect: Reproduction of pain with passive dorsiflexion of the toes can be seen in compartment syndrome. Patients present with severe pain that worsens with passive stretching of the affected muscles, paresthesias, as well as sensory or motor deficits. This patient’s intermittent leg pain is suggestive of peripheral arterial disease. 
❌ Lack of femoral vein compressibility on doppler ultrasound :
Incorrect: Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremities is used for the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Patients typically present with leg swelling, pain, warmth, and erythema in the presence of significant risk factors (e.g., history of immobilization or prolonged hospitalization, recent surgery, or trauma). This patient has multiple atherosclerotic risk factors and claudication.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of bilateral leg “heaviness and aching pain” with prolonged standing. The patient reports that the pain worsens at the end of the day and is relieved by walking or elevating her feet. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and obesity. Family history is noncontributory. The patient smokes two packs daily and does not use alcohol or other recreational drugs. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the lower extremities demonstrates dilated, tortuous veins at the calves and ankles bilaterally, without surrounding erythema, edema, or ulceration. A bluish non-tender lump is noted in the right upper thigh, inferior to the inguinal ligament, that disappears with continuous, direct pressure and with lying supine. No pulsations are felt and no inguinal defect is palpated. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s groin swelling?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with lower limb varicosities, most likely due to prolonged standing and obesity, as well as a bluish-tinged, nontender, reducible groin lump suggestive of a saphena varix.   

Saphena varix is a dilated, saccular swelling of the great saphenous vein at the saphenofemoral junction in the groin below the inguinal ligament. They arise from incompetent valves, which permit blood flow from the deep venous system to the superficial venous system. Thus the leg of the affected side almost always has obvious varicose veins as well which are tortuous dilated segments of a vein associated with valvular incompetence. This results in venous hypertension and dilatation of the superficial venous system. Valvular incompetence of the deep and superficial veins can be determined by performing a Trendelenburg test. The affected leg is raised emptying the veins, then a tourniquet is applied to constrict only the superficial veins. The test is positive, if upon standing with the tourniquet in place for 30 seconds, the varicosities remain collapsed and when the tourniquet is removed, the internal saphenous vein rapidly fills with blood from above. This indicates that the valves of the saphenous vein at the saphenofemoral junction are incompetent, but the valves of the communicating veins are still intact.  



Option Analysis

❌ Femoral hernia:
Incorrect: A femoral hernia results when the abdominal viscera passes through the femoral ring. The inguinal defect can typically be palpated. This condition manifests as a tender or non-tender bulge on the upper thigh, inferior to the inguinal ligament, and can often be mistaken for a saphena varix..
❌ Femoral artery aneurysm:
Incorrect: A femoral artery aneurysm refers to dilation of the common femoral artery just below the inguinal ligament. Pain is typically absent in femoral artery aneurysms and the palpable mass is typically pulsatile. 
✅ Saphena varix:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Direct inguinal hernia:
Incorrect: Inguinal hernias are located above the inguinal ligament and medial to the pubic tubercle. This patient’s groin lump is located below the inguinal ligament.
❌ Inguinal lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Enlarged inguinal lymph nodes vary in consistency, number, presence of pain, and size depending on the pathological cause. Lymph nodes are not reducible.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to sudden-onset confusion and headaches accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The patient has a history of poorly controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia due to noncompliance with medications. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 205/140 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is dyspneic. Fundoscopic examination reveals bilateral papilledema. Laboratory results are obtained and shown below:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum 
 Creatinine   1.9 mg/dL 
 Blood urea nitrogen  50 mg/dL 
 Urine  
 Erythrocytes  8/hpf 
 Leukocytes  2/hpf 
 Protein  3+ 
 Sediment   None 
Which of the following histologic findings would likely be seen if this patient’s renal artery was biopsied?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of uncontrolled hypertension now presents with extremely high blood pressure (>180/120) and signs of end-organ damage (e.g., confusion, headache, blurry vision). Along with the laboratory results (i.e., elevated creatinine and hematuria), this presentation is consistent with malignant hypertension, also known as hypertensive emergency.  

 Hypertensive emergencies are often the result of hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis, which is characterized by concentric thickening (“onion skinning”) of the arteries and arterioles due to smooth muscle proliferation. In hypertensive emergency, these changes are acutely accompanied by fibrinoid deposits and vessel wall necrosis (necrotizing arteriolitis), which are more pronounced in the kidney. The result is a marked narrowing of renal arterioles and small arteries, which causes significantly reduced blood flow and subsequent ischemia, resulting in acute kidney failure.   

Arteriosclerosis literally means “stiffening of the arteries,” and the differences between different types of arteriosclerosis are shown in the table below:  



Option Analysis

❌  Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons :
Incorrect: This histology slide depicts hyaline arteriosclerosis, a condition that is associated with essential hypertension and diabetes mellitus. The condition is characterized by protein deposition and luminal narrowing. The proteins are seen as pink, hyaline, amorphous material under the microscope. Although this patient may have some degree of hyaline arteriosclerosis, this sudden-onset hypertensive emergency more likely resulted in hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis. 
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons:
Incorrect: This histology slide depicts Mönckeberg sclerosis (medial calcific sclerosis), an uncommon condition which leads to calcification of the internal elastic lamina and media. Usually the condition is asymptomatic and is found as an incidental finding on imaging.
✅ Reproduced from: Wikipedia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons:
Incorrect: This histology slide depicts a complex atheroma, characteristic of atherosclerosis. It usually affects elastic arteries and large- and medium-sized muscular arteries, due to build up of cholesterol plaques. Although this patient probably has concomitant atherosclerosis, this severe hypertension will likely manifest as hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis in the renal arteries.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a one day history of dull chest pain. The patient reports he was out for a jog yesterday when he suddenly experienced dull chest pain radiating to the back, with associated shortness of breath. The patient reports he is otherwise healthy but has smoked 5-10 cigarettes per day for the past ten years. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 130/66 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 99% on room air. He does not appear to be in acute distress. Physical examination shows a thin, tall man, with a concave anterior chest wall. Cardiovascular examination shows 2+ pulses in the upper extremities bilaterally, and a mid-systolic murmur at the cardiac apex is heard on auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has features of Marfan syndrome, including pectus excavatum (concave anterior chest wall) and mitral valve prolapse, given the mid-systolic murmur at the cardiac apex on examination. Both of these features, in conjunction with a history of smoking and dull chest pain radiating to the back, are concerning features for a diagnosis of a thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA).  

TAAs are true aneurysms, meaning all three layers of the blood vessel - intima, media, and adventitia - are dilated >50% greater of the normal diameter of the aorta. Other risk factors for thoracic aortic aneurysms include hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Significant genetic risk factors aside from Marfan syndrome include other inherited connective tissue disorders such as Loeys-Dietz and vascular type Ehlers-Danlos syndromes, large vessel inflammatory diseases such as giant cell arteritis and Takayasu's aortitis, as well as infections such as tertiary syphilis.    

Most cases of TAAs are silent, meaning they do not produce symptoms until they are large enough to compress on adjacent structures. The symptoms of TAAs depend largely on their location: 
  •  Aneurysms of the aortic arch result in ascending aneurysms and can present signs of aortic regurgitation due to dilation of the aortic valve annulus; this can eventually progress to heart failure. In addition, symptoms can be related to compression of nearby structures: for example, the coronary arteries (chest pain) as seen in this patient, the tracheobronchial tree (wheezing) or the esophagus (dysphagia). 
  •  Aneurysms of the descending aorta are less likely to lead to symptoms until the aneurysm has become very large due to the capacity of the thoracic cavity. If large enough, the aneurysm can affect the adjacent spine, causing back pain.  




Option Analysis

❌ Aortic dissection:
Incorrect: While people with marfanoid habitus and thoracic aortic aneurysms are at risk for the development of aortic dissection, the clinical presentation is usually much more severe. Patients are often extremely uncomfortable, hypertensive, and describe a sensation of ripping or tearing chest pain radiating to the back.  
✅ Thoracic aortic aneurysm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Coronary artery disease :
Incorrect: While compression of the coronary arteries may occur with large aortic aneurysms, inducing dull chest pain, the patient in this vignette is less likely to have true coronary artery disease from atherosclerosis.  
❌ Pulmonary embolism:
Incorrect: Pulmonary embolism (PE) can be associated with shortness of breath, but are typically described as pleuritic, or sharp pain with deep inhalation. Patients with pulmonary embolisms typically present with either tachycardia, hypoxia, or non-specific T-wave changes on ECG. The patient in this vignette does not have typical PE risk factors such as recent travel, malignancy, or family history of clotting disorder.  
❌ Costochondritis :
Incorrect: Costochondritis remains an incredibly common cause of musculoskeletal chest pain in otherwise young, healthy individuals. It is a diagnosis of exclusion made by first ruling out dangerous pathology. It is less likely in this patient with marfanoid habitus, an ejection click, and ECG changes.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man comes to the clinic due to the recent appearance of skin lesions. The patient's history is significant for chronic asthma, recurrent sinusitis, and nasal polyposis. On physical examination, tender subcutaneous nodules are present on the bilateral shins. The results of the white blood cell differential are shown below:

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Leukocyte count  16,000/mm3 
 Neutrophils, segmented  44% 
 Neutrophils, banded  5% 
 Eosinophils  29% 
 Basophils  0% 
 Lymphocytes  15% 
 Monocytes  7% 
 
 This patient’s condition is associated with antibodies directed against which of the following?
questions.solution:
This young patient with a history significant for chronic asthma, recurrent sinusitis, and nasal polyposis, now presents with new skin lesions and marked eosinophilia, and therefore, he most likely has eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss).    

Patients with vasculitis have circulating antibodies that react with neutrophil cytoplasmic antigens termed antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs). ANCAs are a heterogeneous group of autoantibodies directed against neutrophil primary granules elements (mainly enzymes). ANCAs are useful diagnostic markers, and their titers mirror clinical severity and predictor of disease recurrence. ANCAs are classified accordintosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis).


Option Analysis

❌  Basement membrane:
Incorrect: Anti-basement membrane antibodies are seen in Goodpasture syndrome, an autoimmune disorder characterized by rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis and hemoptysis.  
❌ Microsome:
Incorrect: Antimicrosomal antibodies are seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis, an autoimmune disorder leading to hypothyroidism.  
❌ Transglutaminase enzyme:
Incorrect: IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies are seen in celiac disease, a gluten-sensitive enteropathy. 
✅ Myeloperoxidase enzyme :
Correct: See Main explanation. 
❌ Mitochondria:
Incorrect: Antimitochondrial antibodies are seen in primary biliary cholangitis, an autoimmune disorder characterized by fibrosis of the bile duct and signs of cholestasis. 
❌ Proteinase:
Incorrect: Anti-proteinase-3 antibodies (PR3-ANCA) are seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis, an autoimmune vasculitis characterized by upper and lower respiratory tract involvement, as well as renal involvement.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man comes to the office due to 6 days of eye redness and pain in both eyes. Medical history is significant for recurrent painful oral ulcers and ankylosing spondylitis. He currently takes aspirin and sulfasalazine. The patient is in a monogamous relationship but is unsure sure if his partner is monogamous. The patient immigrated from Turkey when he was a child. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows warm and tender nodules over bilateral shins as well as his left ankle, as shown in the image below:

Reproduced from: Wikipedia

 On ophthalmological examination, decreased visual acuity, conjunctival redness, and hypopyon are noted bilaterally. Genital exam reveals an incipient genital ulceration over the scrotal raphe. Laboratory studies show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. This patient most likely has which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This patient who developed signs and symptoms of anterior uveitis (i.e., decreased visual acuity, conjunctival redness, hypopyon), genital ulceration, painful aphthous ulcers, and erythema nodosum (i.e. tender nodules over the shins and left ankle) likely has Behçet disease.    

The underlying cause of Behçet syndrome is unknown, and several mechanisms have been suggested, including immune complexes from antibodies production and vascular endothelial activation with subsequent hypercoagulability. The condition involves blood vessels of all sizes (small, medium, and large), including both the arterial and venous circulation. This condition has a high incidence among eastern Asia and Mediterranean countries. Behçet disease is strongly associated with HLA-B51 antigens, and it may be precipitated by certain pathogens such as herpes simplex virus, parvovirus infections, and streptococcal infections.  

Obtaining medical history is an important aspect of the diagnosis of Behçet disease. Common clinical findings include (1) recurrent aphthous ulcers or genital ulcerations, (2) uveitis, and (3) erythema nodosum. Other systems may be involved, including CNS, renal, pulmonary, cardiac, musculoskeletal, and gastrointestinal. Patients often present with pathergy, a skin condition in which a minor trauma leads to the development of skin lesions or ulcers resistant to healing.  

Behçet disease attacks generally last 1-4 weeks, and if left untreated, patients may progress to develop permanent vision loss. Medical treatment for Behçet disease includes anti-inflammatory medications, high-dose corticosteroids, and TNF inhibitors (e.g., infliximab, etanercept).    


Option Analysis

❌  Ankylosing spondylitis relapse :
Incorrect: Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of systemic inflammatory arthritis in which there is long-term inflammation of the joints of the spine. It may also be associated with nonarticular features including uveitis, psoriasis, and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). A relapse is characterized by the deterioration of initial symptoms, such as dull pain in the lower back combined with lower back stiffness, none of which is present in this patient.  
❌ Aphthous stomatitis:
Incorrect: Aphthous stomatitis (or "canker sore") is a common condition characterized by the repeated formation of benign and non-contagious mouth ulcers in healthy individuals. In this case, the patient has additional signs and symptoms (genital ulcers, uveitis) which are indicative of another condition.   
✅ Behçet disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Primary syphilis:
Incorrect: Primary syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Treponema pallidum. Primary syphilis is particularly characterized by a syphilitic chancre (single, firm, painless, non-itchy skin ulceration), which normally appears at the point of contact. However, the presence of multiple aphthous ulcers in the oral cavity and eye inflammation is not present in syphilis. 
❌ Reactive arthritis:
Incorrect: Reactive arthritis (or Reiter syndrome) is an autoimmune condition characterized by conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis. This condition is strongly associated with HLA-B27 serology and is usually seen after infection with Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, and Chlamydia trachomatis species. Reactive arthritis can present with many similar features seen in Behçet disease; however, the oral lesions in reactive arthritis are not painful, and erythema nodosum is very rare in patients with reactive arthritis.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to the clinic due to fatigue, joint pain, and recent appearance of skin lesions on his legs. His medical history is noncontributory except for a car accident as a child which required hospitalization and multiple blood transfusions. He has not seen a physician in more than 10 years. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. He is monogamous with one sexual partner. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical exam shows purpuric papules covering the lower extremities that do not blanch with pressure. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory tests are obtained and shown below:  

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin   15 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count   7,000/mm3 
 Platelets    250,000/mm3 
 ALT  110 U/L 
 AST  75 U/L 
 Rheumatoid factor   Positive   
 Antinuclear antibodies  Negative  
 
 Urinalysis is unremarkable. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation reveals polyclonal IgG and monoclonal IgM bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitation after 24 hours. Which of the following tests is most likely to reveal this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with purpura, arthralgias, and weakness (Meltzer triad) in association with positive rheumatoid factor test and confirmatory electrophoresis results, has cryoglobulinemia (type II). Mixed cryoglobulinemia syndrome is most often due to chronic hepatitis C infection. The patient's age and history of blood transfusions as a child put him at increased risk for hepatitis C infection. An additional clue is this patient’s elevated liver enzymes, suggesting a chronic liver condition.  

Cryoglobulins are immunoglobulins that precipitate in the cold temperatures and dissolve on rewarming. Cryoglobulins that contain more than one type of immunoglobulin component are called mixed cryoglobulins (e.g., monoclonal/polyclonal IgM, IgG, IgA antibodies, monoclonal κ or λ free light chain portions of these antibodies, and proteins of the blood complement system). The pathogenesis of the condition is poorly understood and assumed to be related to higher production of immunoglobulin, increased precipitation of immune complexes, and insufficient clearance. In type I cryoglobulinemia, precipitates are often seen within 24 hours. However, 3-5 days are usually needed in patients with mixed cryoglobulins, as well as type II cryoglobulins, which requires up to 7 days for precipitation.  

Clinical manifestations commonly include purpura, arthralgias, weakness and possibly peripheral neuropathy, and renal involvement (e.g. glomerulonephritis).

Option Analysis

✅  Hepatitis C serology  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ PCR for N. gonorrhea:
Incorrect: The classic presentation of disseminated N. gonorrhoea infection includes tenosynovitis, dermatitis, and polyarthralgia. Skin lesions are usually pustular or vesiculopustular (although papules can also occur). Moreover, this patient had no history of unprotected sex or sexually transmitted disease, and the urinalysis was normal.   
❌ Serum anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA):
Incorrect: Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA)-associated vasculitis is a group of diseases which includes granulomatosis with polyangiitis, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and microscopic polyangiitis. Although (ANCA)-associated vasculitis can present with similar symptoms, other characteristics would be expected, such as nasopharyngeal involvement (granulomatosis with polyangiitis) or atopic history with eosinophilia (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis). Moreover, the patient’s electrophoresis results favor another diagnosis.  
❌  Rapid plasma reagin test (RPR) :
Incorrect: Rapid plasma reagin test is a screening test for syphilis. Secondary syphilis can present with fever, lymphadenopathy, skin rashes and condylomata lata. Although the rash seen in secondary syphilis can be papular, this patient has no history of unprotected sex or sexually transmitted diseases. 
❌ Antibodies to rickettsiae:
Incorrect: Rickettsiae infection is caused by fleas or ticks and usually presents with a classic triad of headache, fever, and rash (vasculitis). The rash seen in rickettsiae is not limited to the lower extremities. This patient’s rash pattern, symptoms, and laboratory findings favor another diagnosis.  
❌ Bone marrow biopsy:
Incorrect: Bone marrow biopsy can help establish the underlying diagnosis in patients with type I cryoglobulinemia. Type I cryoglobulinemia is associated with monoclonal gammopathies (e.g., MGUS, multiple myeloma) or hematologic malignancies (e.g. chronic lymphocytic leukemia). This patient blood count is normal, and his electrophoresis and precipitation test supports the diagnosis of type II cryoglobulinemia (See Main Explanation). 
❌ Antibodies to citrullinated peptide antigens:
Incorrect: This patient is found positive for rheumatoid factor (IgM antibody that targets IgG Fc region), which is not specific and can be found in many diseases, including cryoglobulinemia. In patients with suspected rheumatoid arthritis, positive test for rheumatoid factor will be followed by testing for anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody (more specific) to confirm the diagnosis. Rheumatoid arthritis does not present with palpable purpura on the lower extremities, and other symptoms would be expected.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after experiencing several episodes of non-bilious and non-bloody emesis, followed by a sudden onset of intense chest pain radiating to the back. She also notes that she has left arm weakness. The patient states that prior to today, she has been in her usual state of health. She drinks a pint of vodka daily and regularly uses intranasal cocaine. She reports last using cocaine this morning. Her temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 210/120 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient appears disheveled and in significant distress. Physical examination shows 1+ peripheral pulses in the right upper extremity and 2+ pulses in the left upper extremity. Neurological examination shows 3/5 power in the left upper and lower extremities compared to 5/5 power in the right upper and lower extremities. Laboratory markers demonstrate a troponin of 0.7 ng/ml and a WBC of 12,000/mm3. ECG demonstrates ST-depressions in leads II, III, and aVF. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Aneurysmal rupture of the left middle cerebral artery
Longitudinal cleavage of the aortic media
Atherosclerotic rupture of a right coronary artery plaque
Full thickness perforation of the esophagus

questions.solution:
This patient in this vignette has concerning features for an aortic dissection given her risk factors of uncontrolled hypertension, in addition to the associated clinical features of a widened pulse pressure and characteristic neurologic deficits. Patients with aortic dissections classically present with sudden onset, sharp or tearing chest pain that radiates to the back, syncope, widened pulse pressure, and occasionally differing blood pressure in the upper extremities with associated neurologic deficits.  

Aortic dissections are caused by prolonged hydrodynamic shear stress on the intima of the vessel, which eventually creates a tear in the intimal layer and a column of blood gains access into the aortic media. With repetitive hydrodynamic stress the column of blood longitudinally tears through the media either retrograde (towards the heart), anterograde (away from the heart), or both. Eventually, the hematoma compresses on adjacent structures depending on where the dissection travels. For example, it may compress the brachiocephalic trunk or carotid arteries causing a stroke, or if proximal it may compress the right coronary artery causing an inferior wall MI, as in this patient with changes consistent with an NSTEMI. The hematoma may progress into the pericardium, causing pericardial tamponade.  

The most common risk factor aortic dissection is uncontrolled hypertension, likely precipitated by her chronic cocaine. Genetic risk factors include a history of connective tissue diseases likely Ehlers-Danlos syndrome or Marfan syndrome, which predispose to an already weakened aorta from thoracic aortic aneurysms. Infectious or inflammatory risk factors include Takayasu arteritis, giant cell arteritis, Behçet disease, and syphilis, which also weaken the aortic intima and predispose to intimal tearing.  

 


 The diagnosis of aortic dissection is made by careful physical examination, history, in addition to imaging findings of a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray and a visible dissection flap on CT-angiography of the aorta. If left untreated, aortic dissections can lead to end organ ischemia or rupture, causing hemodynamic instability and death.  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia Commons  

Option Analysis

❌ Aneurysmal rupture of the left middle cerebral artery  :
Incorrect: While rupture of a berry aneurysm may lead to neurologic manifestations as in this patient, patients are typically obtunded or endorse a severe “thunderclap” headache prior to the onset of symptoms.    
✅ Longitudinal cleavage of the aortic media:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Atherosclerotic rupture of a right coronary artery plaque:
Incorrect: The ECG changes in this vignette are typical of an NSTEMI of the inferior wall of the heart, which can be seen with rupture of a right coronary artery plaque. However, the patient in this vignette is extremely hypertensive, and she is more likely experiencing vaso-occlusion and subsequent ischemia of the right coronary artery due to compression from an expanding dissection.  
❌ Full thickness perforation of the esophagus :
Incorrect: Boerhaave's syndrome, or full thickness rupture of the esophagus, can present with severe retrosternal chest pain radiating to the back, especially after multiple episodes of vomiting and recent alcoholic binge as in this vignette. However, patients will usually be vomiting copious amounts of blood, which is absent from this patient’s presentation.  
❌ Defect in lung ventilation/perfusion ratio:
Incorrect: Pulmonary embolisms present with a V/Q mismatch, which is a defect in the ratio of ventilation to perfusion. Patients with large pulmonary embolisms will often present with hypoxia, hypotension, and tachycardia, which are not present in this patient.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a one week history of a red, painful swollen left lower extremity. The patient reports he recently returned from Hawaii, where he was running a marathon. He reports his symptoms began shortly after landing and is worried he may have injured his leg during the race. His medical history is non-contributory. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6 °F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 152/73 mmHg, and oxygen saturation saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination shows a swollen and mildly erythematous left lower extremity that is painful to palpation, with 2+ pitting edema compared to the right lower extremity. Pulses are 2+ with capillary refill <2 seconds bilaterally. WBC is 9000/mm3 and creatine kinase is 30U/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: CT-angiogram of the left lower extremity

questions.solution:
This patient likely has a deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which classically presents as a unilateral, swollen, erythematous, and painful lower extremity. Virchow's triad summarizes the pathophysiology leading to thrombosis, and includes endothelial injury, hypercoagulability, and venous stasis. Venous stasis occurs during periods of extended immobility, including long-distance plane flights (as in this patient), hospital stays, post-op, or sedentary lifestyles.  

The differential diagnosis of a deep vein thrombosis includes cellulitis, compartment syndrome, fractures, and a ruptured Baker's cyst. Of all the diagnostic investigations listed, a compression ultrasound with doppler of the deep veins of the leg is the most appropriate diagnostic study to obtain.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Left tibia and fibula x-ray:
Incorrect: While a stress fracture is possible in a patient with a recent long distance run, it is unlikely given the presence of pitting edema on exam.  
✅ Ultrasound of the lower extremities:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CT-angiogram of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect: CTA of the lower extremity is indicated if there is concern for vaso-occlusive disease of the arteries of the lower extremity. This condition presents with pallor, poor capillary refill, mottled extremities and often non-palpable or diminished pulses, which this patient does not have.   
❌ Measurement of compartment pressures:
Incorrect: Measurement of compartment pressures is indicated when there is concern for compartment syndrome. On physical examination, this condition does present with swelling, but more often there are tense muscles rather than pitting edema. This patient’s CK level is also normal, making this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ Blood cultures:
Incorrect: Blood cultures would be indicated in the setting of cellulitis. This diagnosis is unlikely in an afebrile patient with a normal white blood cell count.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinician's office by his parent because of a 1-day history of rash, nausea, and stomach pain. The parent reports the patient had a throat infection several weeks ago which resolved spontaneously. A few days later, he developed a hip pain that subsided and was followed by right knee and ankle pain. At the same time, he developed a rash on his legs, buttocks, and forearms. Immunizations are up to date. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a rash, as shown in the image below. Musculoskeletal examination reveals a swollen right knee without effusion, erythema, or warmth. Scrotal swelling and sensitivity are noted on the left side. Urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria with proteinuria. Serum electrolytes, including creatinine, are within normal limits.

Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

 Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child, who is presenting with palpable purpura/petechiae, migratory arthritis, and abdominal pain that all occurred following an upper respiratory/throat infection, most likely has IgA vasculitis, formerly known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP). Other possible manifestations may include hematuria, proteinuria, intussusception, gastrointestinal hemorrhage, scrotal swelling and pain, as well as CNS and eye involvement.    

IgA-antibody immune complexes caused by antigenic exposure from an infection (such as a Streptococcal infection) or medication, deposit in the small vessels (usually capillaries) of the skin, joints, kidneys, and GI tract. This deposition results in an influx of inflammatory mediators such as prostaglandins. If the immune complexes are deposited in the intestinal wall, they may cause GI hemorrhage; intussusception is a major complication of HSP. Renal involvement of IgA-mediated immune complexes may result in crescentic glomerulonephritis. Immune complex deposits in the skin cause palpable purpura and petechiae.  

The management of HSP is mainly symptomatic and supportive, with therapy directed toward adequate oral hydration, bed rest, and symptomatic relief of joint and abdominal pain. Patients with joint pain can be treated with NSAIDs; in severe cases, oral steroids may be indicated.  

Option Analysis

✅ IgA vasculitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌  Juvenile idiopathic arthritis :
Incorrect: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis is a systemic condition characterized by daily fever in a quotidian pattern (occurring daily), lymphadenopathy, rash, and arthritis. The rash is usually a macular, salmon-pink rash. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Mumps infection:
Incorrect: Mumps is a viral illness that mostly can be prevented by vaccination. Vaccination is given in 3 doses as the MMR vaccine (mumps, measles, rubella) and is completed by 6 years of age. Patients typically present with a few days of fever, headache, myalgia, fatigue, and anorexia, followed by parotitis and orchitis. Mumps is not associated with rash, and this child is fully vaccinated, which makes mumps unlikely.  
❌ Rheumatic fever:
Incorrect: Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory disease that typically develops two to four weeks after a streptococcal throat infection and can involve the heart, joints, skin, and brain. The rash, known as erythema marginatum, is pink, non-itchy, and usually found on the torso and inner surfaces of the limbs. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Childhood-onset systemic lupus erythematosus:
Incorrect: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune inflammatory disease of unknown cause that can involve any organ system, most commonly the joints, skin, kidneys, and the nervous, hematologic, and cardiovascular systems. Childhood-onset systemic lupus erythematosus presents similar to adults but tends to be more severe. Patients may present with serositis, oral ulcers, arthritis, photosensitivity, blood cytopenias, renal disease, neurologic symptoms, and malar rash/discoid rash.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 36-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to headaches, lightheadedness, diffuse arthralgia, and numbness in the hands for the past week. She also reports fatigue and waking up in the middle of the night “soaked in sweat.” She does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), and blood pressure is 140/95 mmHg in the left arm and 110/65 in the right arm. Physical examination reveals a weak right radial pulse. A systolic bruit is heard over the right subclavian artery. Laboratory results are obtained and shown below:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  10.1  g/dL 
 Hematocrit  31% 
 Leukocyte count  12,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  550,000/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  80 mm/h 
 Serum C-reactive protein  35 mg/dL (N=0.08–3.1) 
 
 Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Takayasu arteritis (TA) is a large-vessel vasculitis that mainly affects the aorta and its branches. It is most often seen in women at ages 10-40 years, especially of Asian descent. Patients initially present with constitutional symptoms (e.g., night sweats, fatigue), followed by symptoms associated with vascular damage.    

The pathogenesis is poorly understood but appears to occur in a similar pathogenetic mechanism to temporal arteritis. TA is characterized as an inflammatory granulomatous vasculitis of medium- and large-sized arteries, which leads to transmural fibrous thickening of the arterial walls, resulting in multiple vascular obstructions and eventual ischemic changes. Arterial wall inflammation is characterized by a predominance of CD4+ T lymphocytes and macrophages, which undergo granulomatous organization and formation of giant cells. The inflammation induces vascular remodeling that leads to intimal hyperplasia and lumen occlusion.  

The following features may be seen:  
  •  Constitutional symptoms: low-grade fever, weight loss, fatigue 
  •  Cardiovascular: Absent or weak peripheral pulses, limb claudication, blood pressure discrepancy between arms, hypertension, angina, myocardial infarction 
  •  Musculoskeletal: arthralgias, myalgias 
  •  Dermatological: skin lesions similar to erythema nodosum or pyoderma gangrenosum 
  •  Neurologic symptoms, caused by involvement of the carotid and vertebral arteries: lightheadedness, vertigo, syncope, headaches, and strokes 
  •  Laboratory findings: elevated ESR, CRP, anemia of chronic disease, thrombocytosis and leukocytosis 
Since TA is primarily an autoimmune condition, initial treatment of symptomatic TA begins with corticosteroids. In more severe conditions, surgical revascularization is a possible therapy as well.




Option Analysis

❌ Polyarteritis nodosa:
Incorrect: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) also presents with constitutional symptoms (e.g., night sweats, fatigue) and signs of systemic inflammation (e.g. elevated ESR and CRP); however, weak pulses are not seen in PAN. Instead, patients often present with renal insufficiency/hypertension and mononeuropathy multiplex.  
❌ Temporal arteritis:
Incorrect: Temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis) also presents with constitutional symptoms (e.g., night sweats, fatigue) and signs of systemic inflammation (e.g. elevated ESR and CRP); however, patients are usually above the age of 50. Moreover, patients often present with a history of scalp/temporal pain and jaw claudication. 
✅ Takayasu arteritis :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Microscopic polyangiitis :
Incorrect: Microscopic polyangiitis (MP) also presents with constitutional symptoms (e.g., night sweats, fatigue) and signs of systemic inflammation (e.g. elevated ESR and CRP); however, patients often present with skin lesions (palpable purpura), renal involvement, neurologic deficits, and ear, nose, and throat manifestations. In addition, weak pulses are not expected because MP involves small-sized arteries.     
❌ Thromboangiitis obliterans:
Incorrect: Thromboangiitis obliterans typically affects men who smoke and presents with distal signs of ischemia and ulcerations and Raynaud phenomenon. Due to segmental inflammatory disease affecting small to medium-sized arteries and veins of the extremities, decreased pulses can also be seen. However, this patient does not smoke, and her clinical presentation favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Granulomatosis with polyangiitis:
Incorrect: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), also called Wegner Granulomatosis, also presents with constitutional symptoms (e.g., night sweats, fatigue) and signs of systemic inflammation (e.g. elevated ESR and CRP); however, patients often present with skin lesions (palpable purpura), renal involvement, neurologic deficits, and ear, nose, and throat manifestations. In addition, weak pulses are not expected because GPA involves small-sized arteries. The presentation of GPA is similar to microscopic polyangiitis.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man comes to the emergency department with sudden, severe leg pain. He was watching football at home when he experienced an acute-onset, sharp pain in the right calf that has progressively worsened. The patient reports being unable to feel the sock worn on that foot, and he is having difficulty moving his toes. He denies chest pain or shortness of breath. Medical history is significant for a small intracranial aneurysm that has been monitored on serial imaging and has remained stable in size for five years. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is irregularly irregular at 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical exam shows pale and mottled skin starting 6 cm below the right tibial plateau and extending to the right toes. There is no swelling. Hair growth is normal. Carotid, radial, and femoral pulses are palpable bilaterally. The left posterior tibial artery pulse is palpable while his right is absent on palpation and has no signal on Doppler ultrasound. Which of the following locations is the most likely origin of this patient’s embolus?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with sudden onset unilateral leg pain with evidence on examination of critical limb ischemia. Acute (critical) limb ischemia, defined as occurring within 2 weeks of symptom onset, is most often caused by acute arterial occlusion in patients with known peripheral artery disease (PAD). However, the condition can occur in previously healthy patients in the setting of arterial dissection, trauma, or embolism from a more proximal source. This patient does not have risk factors for atherosclerosis (e.g., hypertension, diabetes, smoking) and the peripheral pulses are normal in all but the affected leg, suggesting an embolic occlusion, as depicted on the right in this diagram:  



The majority of peripheral emboli originate in the heart, either from atrial thrombus in the setting of atrial fibrillation, ventricular thrombus in the setting of myocardial infarction, or vegetations in the setting of infective endocarditis.

This patient has no symptoms or history of myocardial infarction and no fevers or murmur to suggest endocarditis. Therefore, the patient most likely has a thromboembolism from a left atrial appendage clot in the setting of atrial fibrillation (irregularly irregular heartbeat), which then lodged in the popliteal artery (the occlusion is usually found one joint above the line of pale skin on exam).  

On physical exam, the “six P’s” (pain, pallor, poikilothermia [cool], pulselessness, paresthesia, paralysis) suggest acute limb ischemia. Pain starts suddenly and gradually increases in severity. It is associated with cool, pale, and mottled skin. Distal pulses are severely diminished or absent. Paresthesias and paralysis indicate severe ischemia and hypoxic nerves. Urgent revascularization is necessary to prevent loss of limb.   

Option Analysis

❌ Right popliteal vein:
Incorrect: The right popliteal vein may become occluded in the setting of a deep venous thrombosis (DVT). Thromboembolism from DVT is most likely to result in pulmonary embolism, though rarely a venous thrombus can enter arterial circulation through a patent foramen ovale (PFO). DVT is usually associated with asymmetric leg swelling.  
❌ Right femoral vein:
Incorrect: The right femoral vein may become occluded in the setting of a deep venous thrombosis (DVT). Thromboembolism from DVT is most likely to result in pulmonary embolism, though rarely a venous thrombus can enter arterial circulation through a patent foramen ovale (PFO). DVT is usually associated with asymmetric leg swelling.  
✅ Left atrium:
Correct: See Main Explanation below.  
❌ Left ventricle:
Incorrect: A thrombus may form in the left ventricle following a myocardial infarction, where akinetic, infarcted myocardium becomes a nidus for clot formation. Left ventricular clots may embolize to the arterial system causing stroke or distal ischemia. This patient does not have symptoms or a history of myocardial infarction.  
❌ Ascending aorta:
Incorrect: Dissection of the ascending aorta may affect perfusion to the upper extremities if it involves the brachiocephalic or subclavian arteries. Aortic dissection usually causes severe chest pain radiating to the back.  
❌ Descending aorta:
Incorrect: Atheroembolism of an aortic cholesterol plaque distally to the leg would be less likely to cause a large arterial occlusion in a patient without evidence of peripheral artery disease. Atheroembolisms are smaller than thromboembolisms and are more likely to cause very distal ischemia in one toe.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a syncopal event at home. He has had two hours of left-sided flank pain radiating to the groin, which is associated with nausea and vomiting. Prior to this episode, he reports vague back pain and fatigue over the past several months. His past medical history is significant for an 80-pack-year smoking history, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension. He has had no previous abdominal surgeries. His BMI is 30 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. Abdominal examination shows distension and diffuse tenderness on palpation, and cardiovascular examination shows a 1+ dorsalis pedis pulse in the left foot and 2+ pulse in the right foot. Laboratory findings show a WBC of 12,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) should be considered in any older individual presenting with sudden onset abdominal, low back, or flank pain and a history of syncope with hypotension.  Risk factors for AAA include significant age >65 years, smoking, male gender, family history of AAA, and other risk factors for coronary artery disease or peripheral vascular disease including hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Abdominal aortic aneurysms are true aneurysms, meaning all three layers of the blood vessel - the intima, media, and adventitia - are dilated. The pathophysiology of abdominal aortic aneurysms is a complex, multifactorial process that involves alterations in the structure of the vascular wall due to inflammatory changes, abnormal collagen remodeling and cross-linking, as well as loss of elastin and smooth muscle cells. This ultimately results in progressive thinning and weakening of the aortic wall and enlargement of the aortic diameter to a dilation 50% greater than the normal diameter of the aorta.  

AAAs commonly occur at the infrarenal level, or below the level of the renal arteries. People with near rupture or rapid expansion of a AAA commonly present with sudden onset back, flank, or abdominal pain and associated symptoms such as nausea and vomiting, mimicking a myriad of other conditions. Other associated symptoms may include diminished peripheral pulses due to expansion of the aneurysm compressing the internal iliac arteries. Although a pulsatile abdominal mass is a classic presentation, it may not always be detectable, especially if the patient is obese, such as in this vignette. If left untreated, AAAs can rupture, leading to severe hypotension, hemodynamic instability, and death. In a case where rupture has not occurred, repair should be offered when the aneurysm is >5 cm.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Renal colic:
Incorrect: Renal colic commonly causes flank pain radiating to the groin with associated nausea and vomiting; however, it rarely causes syncope. Patients commonly describe sharp severe flank pain with associated urinary symptoms, including dysuria and hematuria.   
❌ Acute pancreatitis:
Incorrect: Pancreatitis can present with nausea and vomiting, but it is also commonly associated with distinct mid-epigastric pain radiating to the back and a history of chronic right upper quadrant pain due to gallstones or recent alcohol use, neither of which this patient endorses.   
❌ Bowel obstruction:
Incorrect: Bowel obstructions may present with abdominal distension and pain, as well as nausea and vomiting. They are most commonly associated with a history of adhesions from prior abdominal surgeries. This patient has no past surgical history, making this diagnosis less likely.   
✅ Abdominal aortic aneurysm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Cholangitis:
Incorrect: Cholangitis refers to an ascending infection of the biliary tree. This disease classically presents with right upper quadrant tenderness, fever, and jaundice, referred to as Charcot’s triad. While the patient in this vignette has signs of sepsis including hypotension and tachycardia, there is no evidence of fever or jaundice, making this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent due to a fever for the past six days. The fever has not responded to treatment with acetaminophen. His parent mentions that the patient has refused to eat due to pain in his mouth. During his bath yesterday, the parent also noticed that he has a rash covering his trunk and limbs. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 125/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. Examination shows an irritable-appearing child with a polymorphous rash covering the trunk which peels off near the fingers, as well as bilateral eye injection without exudate. Cervical lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following complications may be seen in this patient if left untreated?
questions.solution:
This child presenting with a high fever for more than 5 days, possible mucositis (pain during feeding), cervical lymphadenopathy, polymorphous desquamating rash, and conjunctival injection most likely has Kawasaki disease. Kawasaki disease, also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome is a medium-vessel vasculitis seen in children under 5 years old. The diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease is in the chart below.

 A) Bilateral, non-exudative conjunctival injection with perilimbal sparing. (B) Strawberry tongue and bright red, swollen lips with vertical cracking and bleeding. (C) Erythematous rash involving perineum. (D) Erythema of the palms, which is often accompanied by painful edema of the dorsa of the hands. (E) Erythema of the soles, and swelling dorsa of the feet. (F) Desquamation of the fingers. (G) Erythema and induration at the site of a previous vaccination with Bacille-Calmette-Guérin (BCG). (H) Perianal erythematous desquamation.  
Reproduced by: Wikimedia Commons

The main complication seen in Kawasaki disease is coronary artery abnormalities, which may include dilation, aneurysm, and/or stenosis. During the acute phase, patients may develop depressed ventricular function, valvular regurgitation, and pericardial effusion. Late complications consist of myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, stenosis, and occlusion. Acute myocardial infarction is the main cause of death in Kawasaki disease, and early treatment with intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) and aspirin is important to avoid this complication. Kawasaki disease is one of the few cases where it is acceptable to treat children with aspirin (generally aspirin is avoided in children due to the risk of developing Reye syndrome).



Option Analysis

❌ Hemorrhagic cystitis:
Incorrect: Hemorrhagic cystitis can occur with adenovirus infection, not Kawasaki disease. Adenovirus presents with non-exudative conjunctival injection, pharyngitis, coryza, otitis media, and diarrhea.  
❌ Glomerulonephritis:
Incorrect: Glomerulonephritis (GN) is a possible complication of rheumatic fever secondary to streptococcal pharyngitis, not Kawasaki disease. Streptococcal pharyngitis presents with a rash, sore throat with exudates, and fever. Although this child has the fever, rash, and oral pain which can occur in streptococcus infection, the rash seen with streptococcal infection is a flushed sandpaper-like rash. Additionally, GN occurs approximately two weeks after the streptococcal infection has been resolved, not during the acute stage.  
❌ Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis:
Incorrect: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a possible complication of measles. Measles presents with a confluent rash which begins at the head and moves downward, cough, coryza and blue white spots on the buccal mucosa (Koplik spots). This child’s presentation with pain during feeding suggests mucositis, which is more consistent with Kawasaki disease.  
❌ Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome:
Incorrect: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome arises from exotoxin-producing S. aureus strains (exfoliative toxin). It typically occurs with bacterial conjunctivitis, iatrogenic wounds, staphylococcal pneumonia, pyomyositis, septic arthritis, or endocarditis. This child does not have any of these conditions, making staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome less likely.  
❌ Reye syndrome:
Incorrect: This syndrome of unknown etiology is characterized by a rash, vomiting, and liver damage. It occurs after a child with a viral illness has been given aspirin to treat a fever. Kawasaki disease is actually the rare situation in which a child with fever should receive aspirin. Regardless, this child received acetaminophen, not aspirin.  
✅ Mitral regurgitation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and a cough productive of blood-tinged sputum for 3 days. She had a similar episode several weeks ago and was prescribed antibiotics by her family doctor with minimal improvement. Over the past 2 months, she has experienced mild fever, malaise, and weight loss as well as persistent red-tinged rhinorrhea. She does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs.
